hints.content: Start by checking the length of the word. A valid word must contain at least 3 characters. Use a simple conditional statement to verify this requirement.

Next, consider the characters allowed in the word. It should only contain digits and English letters (both uppercase and lowercase). You can use a loop to iterate through each character and check if it meets these criteria.
Identify the vowels in the word. Remember, vowels are 'a', 'e', 'i', 'o', 'u' and their uppercase counterparts. You can store these in a set for quick lookup.
As you check each character, keep track of whether you've found at least one vowel. Use a boolean variable to store this information.
Similarly, you need to check for consonants. A consonant is any English letter that is not a vowel. Ensure you have a way to differentiate between vowels and consonants during your character checks.
After iterating through the word, ensure that both the vowel and consonant flags are true. This will confirm that the word contains at least one of each.
Don't forget to handle edge cases. For example, if the word contains special characters like '@', '#', or '$', it should immediately be considered invalid.
You might want to use a single loop to check for length, valid characters, vowels, and consonants simultaneously. This can make your solution more efficient.
Consider using a counter for vowels and consonants instead of boolean flags. This way, you can easily check if both counts are greater than zero at the end.
Finally, ensure your function returns true only if all conditions are satisfied. If any condition fails, return false. Remember to test your solution with the provided examples and edge cases.

questionNotes: A valid word must have at least 3 characters.
Only digits (0-9) and English letters (uppercase and lowercase) are allowed.
The word must contain at least one vowel and one consonant.
Special characters like '@', '#', and '$' make the word invalid.
The function should return true if the word is valid, otherwise false.
